Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Small-scale testing of nuclear power plant materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
As of 2012, a fraction of the world's energy is supplied by nuclear power plants. The interior environments of the reactors supplying this energy are far from benign. Structural materials in nuclear reactors must withstand decades of high temperatures and pressures, corrosive degradation, and damaging neutron radiation in an environment where safety and reliability are paramount. Of particular concern is radiation damage, which is known to cause unwanted hardening and embrittlement in materials, leading to premature failure. Such damage can be simulated quickly in the lab by focusing a beam of protons on a sample; however, since the protons only penetrate the material to very shallow depths, the testable sample size is limited to the micron scale. With such small samples to work with, traditional materials science tests such as tensile testing cannot be easily performed. To solve this problem, a collaborative effort will be made with radiation damage specialist Dhriti Bhattacharyya at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.

Using focused ion beam (FIB) milling techniques, micron-scale tensile specimens will be manufactured and tested within a scanning electron microscope (SEM). In addition to providing mechanical property measurements, these tests will allow observations the material's local deformation in real time, providing a wealth of information about the failure mechanism of materials in a reactor setting. Microstructural investigations of tested specimens using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) can also be performed to provide further information about the deformation mechanisms involved. Not only will micro-tensile testing have a wide variety of applications in materials research as a whole, but it will also allow a greater number of labs around the world to safely conduct research with small amounts of irradiated and radioactive materials. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of materials suitable for nuclear applications is proving to be a major obstacle to the safety and longevity of nuclear power reactors in many countries. With reactors operating decades beyond their initial lifetimes, trial and error methods for determining which materials can withstand such extreme conditions are simply no longer feasible nor safe. In order to advance knowledge in the nuclear field, basic research on the microstructure of materials must be undertaken. This provides a much better understanding of what is happening to materials on an atomic scale. 

Through this award, efforts were made to explore a materials testing technique that is not yet widely used in the nuclear materials field, but already shows great promise. This technique consists of performing miniaturized micron-scale tensile testing on metal samples within a scanning electron microscope. To quickly simulate the radiation damage that would be caused by a nuclear reactor, the samples were irradiated with an ion beam prior to testing. This allowed for the samples to be handled in typical laboratory facilities, and avoided he need for the expensive equipment typically needed to handle materials that come directly from a nuclear reactor.

Through the course of the project, micro-tensile tests were successfully performed on single-crystal nickel samples that had varying doses of radiation.  During the tests, the real-time deformation in the samples was observed via movies recorded with the microscope. There are many positive outcomes to be gained from this successful experimentation. Now that the procedure for the technique has been developed and demonstrated, many other research facilities around the world can make use of these methods. Very few facilities exist in the world that can handle radioactive materials, but countless modern research labs have the facilities required to conduct these tests since the materials are not radioactive. This will greatly increase the number of laboratories capable of contributing data to understand the effects of radiation in materials. The nuclear energy industry relies on results from these experiments and other similar ones in order to make important decisions about when to replace certain components and when nuclear power plants are operating safely. Therefore, developing the technique of micro-tensile testing is another step forward in providing the information needed to ensure nuclear power is used safely and effectively. 

As a project funded by EAPSI, this study also had profound impacts on the graduate student researcher involved. This student received one-on-one mentoring and career guidance from a senior scientist at a nuclear science laboratory in Australia. Programs such as this allow students to experience research in other nations firsthand, which provides not only practical expertise, but also insight into potential improvements on how research is conducted in the United States.
